citations.narrative:
Acquisition records (including where and when the animal was acquired) was missing for 8 goats and 1 sheep. Lack of
acquisition information doesn't allow for proper tracking by APHIS officials. All acquisition information must be
documented for all regulated animals. Correct by 10/9/24.

A rabbit enclosure housing one rabbit had a hole with sharp points protruding out on the bottom of the enclosure. Sharp
points can cause injury. In addition, the hole could allow for the rabbit to escape or for another animal to enter the
enclosure. The fencing at the bottom of the enclosure must be repaired or replaced so there is no hole for the rabbit to
potentially escape and all sharp points must be eliminated to protect the rabbit from injury. Correct starting on 10/2/24.

An enclosure containing 3 llamas, 3 alpacas, and 2 cows had fence that was mangled with sharp points protruding from it.
Mangled fencing with sharp points protruding outwards can cause injury to the animals. The fencing must be fixed or
replaced so there are no sharp points protruding out from it and it must maintained in good repair to protect the animals
from injury. Correct by 11/2/24.

Clutter was observed surrounding most of the enclosures for the patagonian cavy and the 3 prairie dogs. The clutter
doesn't allow for the enclosures to be properly inspected to ensure there are no holes or hazards where the animals could
escape or injure themselves. It doesn't allow for proper inspection to make sure the area is free of vermin and other pests.
It also makes it difficult to properly maintain and clean the enclosures and the surrounding area. The area around the
enclosures has to be cleaned up so it can be properly inspected. Correct by 10/9/24.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
End of report.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
Acquisition records (including where and when the animal was acquired) was missing for 8 goats and 1 sheep. Lack of 
acquisition information doesn't allow for proper tracking by APHIS officials. All acquisition information must be 
documented for all regulated animals. Correct by 10/9/24. 
3.53(a)(1) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
A rabbit enclosure housing one rabbit had a hole with sharp points protruding out on the bottom of the enclosure. Sharp 
points can cause injury. In addition, the hole could allow for the rabbit to escape or for another animal to enter the 
enclosure. The fencing at the bottom of the enclosure must be repaired or replaced so there is no hole for the rabbit to 
potentially escape and all sharp points must be eliminated to protect the rabbit from injury. Correct starting on 10/2/24. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
An enclosure containing 3 llamas, 3 alpacas, and 2 cows had fence that was mangled with sharp points protruding from it. 
Mangled fencing with sharp points protruding outwards can cause injury to the animals. The fencing must be fixed or 
replaced so there are no sharp points protruding out from it and it must maintained in good repair to protect the animals 
from injury. Correct by 11/2/24. 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
Clutter was observed surrounding most of the enclosures for the patagonian cavy and the 3 prairie dogs. The clutter 
doesn't allow for the enclosures to be properly inspected to ensure there are no holes or hazards where the animals could 
escape or injure themselves. It doesn't allow for proper inspection to make sure the area is free of vermin and other pests. 
It also makes it difficult to properly maintain and clean the enclosures and the surrounding area. The area around the 
enclosures has to be cleaned up so it can be properly inspected. Correct by 10/9/24.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
End of report.
